channel.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
channel.description:
I am working with Davidi2's simple chat program, and adding login methods and such to it. I am trying to have a single packet to handle a persons Username and Password. Using something like a splitter.
For example: Flaming_Kid|\\|1562
The |\\| being the splitter to go between the username and password, to be decided into two strings. "Flaming_Kid" being the username, and "1562" being his password.

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:20, topic:346853”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=443232.msg3255113#msg3255113 date=1278047506]

[quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=443232.msg3254985#msg3254985 date=1278039090]Also note, I don’t use an IDE like alot of people, I just use notepad.
[/quote]Well that is your stupidity…

I actually prefer it that way, I hate the programs assisting me, as it gives no discipline in learning a language. To me, its best to do it without a programs assistance, unless its like a snippet look-up, that shows you the piece of code, and explains it. At least your leaning something from the explanation.

IDE’s are for convenience, they dont have anything to do with discipline, and neither does programming. why waste time finding the exact name of a function instead of pressing ctrl space? why wait till compile time to fix syntax errors?
[/quote]
I have Netbeans on my spare computer running Linux. I only use it when absolutely necessary, because I don’t like things doing work for me. Sure, if its another person, its fine, because at least he/she can tell me, but if i make the mistake, and a program fix’s it while im not paying attention, I wont learn anything from the mistake.[/quote]
but it doesnt fix any mistakes, it tells you about them.

Read full topic
item.source: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?

item.source: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @Hayley1 Hayley;
item.description:
@Hayley1 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:1, topic:346853”]I am working with Davidi2’s simple chat program, and adding login methods and such to it. I am trying to have a single packet to handle a persons Username and Password. Using something like a splitter.

For example:
Flaming_Kid|\|1562

The |\| being the splitter to go between the username and password, to be decided into two strings. “Flaming_Kid” being the username, and “1562” being his password.[/quote]
How about save yourself some time and effort and send the exact same amount of data in two separate strings? For example, what if someone puts |\| in their username or password? Are you going to put more work on yourself by checking for that, too?

Read full topic
item.source: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:20, topic:346853”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=443232.msg3255113#msg3255113 date=1278047506]

[quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=443232.msg3254985#msg3254985 date=1278039090]Also note, I don’t use an IDE like alot of people, I just use notepad.
[/quote]Well that is your stupidity…

I actually prefer it that way, I hate the programs assisting me, as it gives no discipline in learning a language. To me, its best to do it without a programs assistance, unless its like a snippet look-up, that shows you the piece of code, and explains it. At least your leaning something from the explanation.

IDE’s are for convenience, they dont have anything to do with discipline, and neither does programming. why waste time finding the exact name of a function instead of pressing ctrl space? why wait till compile time to fix syntax errors?
[/quote]
I have Netbeans on my spare computer running Linux. I only use it when absolutely necessary, because I don’t like things doing work for me. Sure, if its another person, its fine, because at least he/she can tell me, but if i make the mistake, and a program fix’s it while im not paying attention, I wont learn anything from the mistake.[/quote]

If you don’t like things doing work for you, you probably shouldn’t be using javac. It takes the source code, checks it, and then automatically converts it into bytecode to be ran in the java virtual machine. You could instead write your java programs directly in bytecode and skip the whole javac/compiler thing. It makes just about as much sense as not using a tool to make your life easier, at least a decent text editor with tab support and syntax highlighting. It’s like trying to nail something with a brick instead of a hammer, you will get the job done but it will take much longer and you won’t get as good of an end result.

And again, you would get much better experience from implementing an official, documented protocol such as IRC.

Read full topic

@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:12, topic:346853”]You wan’t to use String.split(delimiter) in this instance.

But, as I told Davidi, it would be a much better learning experience for you if you instead implemented an actual protocol, such as IRC for chat.[/quote]
I am working on the protocol one step at a time. This is merely a learning que, so I can get this setup. I am now working on the GUI, and getting the base protocal setup. (reading user + pass, to determine if you are banned, ip banned, muted.) Mind you I am not the best with regular Java, so this is a completely learning experience even setting up new packets and such.

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

what an effort…

String[] dataSplit = input.split(" "); //assume data is separated by a space
if(dataSplit.length >= 2) //assume you've recieved at least a username & password
    System.out.println("User: "+dataSplit[0]+", Password: "+dataSplit[1]);
else
    throw new IllegalArgumentException("User tried to logon with incorrect protocol"); //means whatever was recieved from the socket wasn't how you wanted it

Read full topic

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:8, topic:346853”]So will i need to set a limit? For example,
String[] params = new String[2000];

I wasn’t sure, because of how the line is setup.

EDIT - Would it be possible to separate a string up by each character within the string, into an array? I would know how to write a method to read it, if dividing it up like that is possible.[/quote]
Do System.out.println(params.length); You’ll see why the error was thrown.

Read full topic

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:6, topic:346853”][quote author=Evil_ link=topic=443232.msg3254719#msg3254719 date=1278025190]

Hmm, I was poking around on google and found the StringTokenizer, and am trying to get it working correctly, since it seems to be exactly what I need, but it keeps returning an error.
Sorry for the spacing, all I did was C-P it from its current position in my code.

                StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input, "~");
                String user = st.nextToken();
                String pass = st.nextToken();
		System.out.println("User: " + user);
                System.out.println("Pass: " + pass);

It is receiving, for example, “flaming_kid~1562” as a string, but it is not separating it like I have been told it should. Instead it returns an error.

String[] params = input.split("~");
String username = params[0];
String password = params[1];
[/quote]
Gives me the same error as what tekk had given me. If I knew more about the entire method about doing this, I could prolly diagnose it myself.
“java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 1”[/quote]
means the index you used for the array was outside of the boundaries of the array.

Read full topic

item.title: Parsing 2 strings from a single string?
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

java.lang.String.split(String regex);

so like this:

String total = "Flaming_Kid::1562";
String[] parts = total.split("::"); 
String user = parts[0];
String pass = parts[1];

Also this is sort of bad btw, it would be better to write the length of the username, then the username, then the length of the password, then the password.

and then on the other side read in the length of the strings then read that many bytes, like this:

// assuming 'dis' is a DataInputStream
int len = dis.readInt();
byte[] strb = new byte[len];
dis.readFully(strb);
String myString = new String(strb);

Read full topic
